children.subject:
Yes I did this:

the pros and cons are up to you. But here are my ideas:

pros:

no more spending time doing assignments and tests you don’t want to do.

cons:

Class schedules the first 3 years are really dense.

1 year ahead of working doesn’t matter long term. Retire at 66. Life is long. Missing college experience is not relevant, you can experience stereotypical college things in just 1 weekend. But with the 3 years you have, that’s more than enough to do a lot of things. But there will be parties after college, going out with friends, and really, everything you do in college. There won’t be a dense area of your college friends after graduation, but 3 years is plenty of time to enjoy seeing friends around school. Good friends will probably be free at least once a month post grad to hangout and have parties or dinners.

stay an extra year and you can take more classes, do another internship, travel more, or you can start working and self study classes, travel on PTO. It doesn’t matter long term, unless you have your own specific pros and cons.

you might be 55 and wish you did 4 years of college, but I think that’s not the best mindset to have anyways. Normal mindset, but 3 years is such a long time to experience college, no need to compare with others who do 4 or more.

ill reiterate, you can party and do other college things after graduation. In terms of being a student researcher and TA, I think you’ll have to be a student. You can intern after graduation too, I’ve seen it happen.

history.content:
Hi,

Just wondering if anyone has insight on the topic. I would imagine that the pros are 1) saving tuition 2) getting ahead in your career, and the cons would be 1) not taking as many classes/majors as you want 2) missing out on a year of the college experience, but that's just my speculation. Does anyone have any personal experiences that inform a deeper or more detailed perspective?
history.subject: Graduating Early EECS, Pros/Cons
